newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Merger mania lifts Brussels bourse to record close.
newsitem.headline: Merger mania lifts Brussels bourse to record close.

text.p: A bout of merger mania -- real and speculated -- blasted the Brussels bourse to a record high close on Friday, and traders said the revitalised nerves of market players could lift it again next week.
"This is definitely good for the market," one trader said. "People were starting to get nervous, but all this talk of takeovers and the implications has been a boost to confidence."
The day started with the suspension of shares in six financial holding companies, followed by news that two -- Almanij and Cobepa -- were splitting a third -- Gevaert -- between them.
Deprived of the chance to play directly with any of the suspended shares, traders went instead for their offshoots.
Almanij unit Kredietbank was a major beneficiary of the attention, rising sharply and becoming the main stock of the day by value.
It ended 3.3 percent up at 14,200 francs in a volume of nearly 30,000 shares, having at one stage hit 14,500 francs.
"What is happening at Almanij could be good news for Kredietbank," one trader said. "Almanij has no cash pile for expanding Kredietbank, but the Gevaert money could give it a lot of options."
"There could be lots of developments. Not now but in the coming weeks and months. Will it expand its banking or insurance activities? It is 'watch this space time,'" the trader added.
At the same time, a newspaper report that insurer Royale Belge was on the verge of being sold to either Switzerland's Winterthur or the Dutch ING banking group, triggered a wave of buying.

Winterthur denied the report, ING and co-Royale Belge owner AXA/UAP refused to comment, and Royale Belge itself said all options remained open. This left the market to dally at will and indulge in whatever fantasies it felt moved by.
Royale Belge shares ended the day 2.4 percent higher at 9,910 francs in a volume of nearly 26,000 shares, having at one stage hit 10,250 francs, a new high.
The insurer holds its annual meeting next Wednesday.
However, it was not the only beneficiary of the activity.
Banque Bruxelles Lambert, part owned by Royale Belge and ING, and the subject of repeated merger talk, climbed 0.6 percent to 9,050 francs, having also hit a new high of 9,100 francs at one stage.
"If ING takes Royale Belge it will give it already more than 30 percent of BBL. That is a strong position," a trader said.
Elsewhere the market simply went along for the ride, helped by the stronger opening on the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

The Bel-20 index of blue chip shares ended 22.24 points or 0.99 percent higher at a new record closing high of 2,267.78, having at one stage come within exactly three points of its all time high of 2,271.54.
